question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: verify()] [Transcript consistency] Must the verifier's transcript operations at lines 379, 385, 391 exactly match the prover's order, or can reordering allow malleability attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Challenge extraction] Can an attacker manipulate the transcript state before challenge_scalar at lines 308, 327-328 to obtain predictable challenges? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: verify()] [Point absorption] Are the append_point operations at lines 385, 391 collision-resistant, or can different group elements produce the same transcript state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Multiple challenge calls] Can calling challenge_scalar multiple times at lines 327-328 from the same transcript state weaken the Fiat-Shamir soundness? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Gamma transcript] Is the gamma challenge at line 544 properly bound to the batch context through transcript, or can it be reused across different batches? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: verify()] [Transcript initialization] Does verify properly initialize a fresh transcript state, or can residual state from previous operations leak into challenge generation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Q_k commitment ordering] Does the foreach at line 307 append q_k_com in consistent order, or can permutation of commitments cause verifier-prover transcript divergence? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: compute_multilinear_quotients()] [Quotient identity] Does the quotient construction at lines 94-111 properly satisfy poly(X) - poly(point) = sum((X_k - point_k) * q_k), or can edge cases violate this identity? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: compute_multilinear_quotients()] [Variable count mismatch] Can assert_eq! at line 84 be bypassed with crafted inputs, allowing mismatched polynomial and point dimensions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: compute_multilinear_quotients()] [Quotient reversal] Why are quotients reversed at line 114, and can this reversal be exploited to create accepting proofs with wrong quotient ordering? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: compute_batched_lifted_degree_quotient()] [Degree shifting] Can the X^{N - d_k - 1} shifting described at lines 142-144 be implemented incorrectly, causing degree-check bypass? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [F polynomial construction] Does the f polynomial construction at lines 338-349 correctly implement f = z*poly.Z + q_hat + eval_term + sum(q_scalars * q_k), or can term ordering affect verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Zero evaluation assertion] The commented assertion at line 350 checks f(x_challenge) == 0 - can removing this check allow non-zero evaluations to pass? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: eval_and_quotient_scalars()] [Scalar formula] Can the scalar formula at lines 220-222 produce incorrect coefficients if challenges are chosen adversarially? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: compute_batched_lifted_degree_quotient()] [Offset return] Why is offset set to 1 << (num_vars - 1) at line 157, and can incorrect offset break KZG opening verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: verify()] [Scalar combination] Does the scalar concatenation at lines 408-412 properly combine all components, or can missing terms allow partial proof forgery? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: polynomial_from_vec()] [Evaluation semantics] Does DenseMultilinearExtension::from_evaluations_vec at line 472 correctly interpret the padded vector as evaluations on the Boolean hypercube? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: commit()] [Hiding property] Does commit_with_randomness at line 256-260 provide computational hiding, or can partial information about poly leak through the commitment? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: commit()] [G1 zero check] Can ZeromorphCommitment default to G1::zero() at line 57 cause issues where the zero commitment is indistinguishable from uninitialized commitments? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Opening soundness] Can the opening proof at lines 355-362 be forged without knowing the committed polynomial, breaking the binding property? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: verify()] [Commitment extraction] Can zeta_z_com computed at line 423-425 be manipulated to extract the committed polynomial from the commitment? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: open()] [Randomness binding] Is the commitment randomness s properly incorporated into the pi proof at line 361, or can proofs be generated without knowing s? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Batch soundness] Does batching with gamma at lines 544-562 preserve soundness, or can an attacker forge a batch proof that wouldn't verify individually? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Function: commit()] [Deterministic commitment] Is the commitment deterministic given (poly, r), or can different internal states produce different commitments for the same inputs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/zeromorph.rs] [Struct: ZeromorphProof] [Proof malleability] Can an attacker modify pi, q_hat_com, or q_k_com components without invalidating the proof, enabling transaction malleability? (High)
